item.title: About me
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: I'm a recent Computer Science grad, and a full time software developer working out of Boise, Idaho. I love to code and learn and hence I have done a little bit of everything when it comes to programming - C#, WPF, Xamarin, Win Forms, Objective-C, Pebble app, Java, Android, Cocoa, iOS, Web Development, Go, Angular etc. I love pixel perfect apps and hence spend many hours perfecting pixels for beautiful apps. I do almost all the UI design myself - from icons to custom UI controls in Sketch and Adobe Fireworks. You name it, I may have done it already. During the day time I work at MetaGeek - an awesome company with even more awesome people. Most of the time we spend our time writing Wi-Fi visualization tools in .NET for almost all major platforms (using Xamarin, of course). But every now and then we also tinker with Objective-C and Java. Some of the beautiful apps that I've worked on, from the time of inception to their final shipping, at MetaGeek can be found on this website: http://inssider.com. I also spend a lot of time doing side projects. Many people have found them useful and have been featured on Lifehacker.com, and at least one has made to the front page of HackerNews. You can download some of these apps from this website itself. Some of the works that I've done are made open source and are available on GitHub: http://github.com/ashokgelal. I'm on Twitter too: http://twitter.com/ashokgelal. I'm more of awesome people follower then a Tweeter. If you want to send me an email then you can find my email address on my GitHub profile. I love people with great sense of humor and hate discriminating people. Please keep this is mind when contacting me. I don't have to say it but please remember, unless explicitly stated, the views and opinions expressed in this website or any public places are of my own and not those of my employer's. Peace.

item.title: Uncertainty, Unstability, and Inconsistency
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've prone to these three notorious words - uncertainty, unstability and inconsistency. I don't know why and I don't remember when I grown the habit of making these three a part of my life. I always find myself running after some damn holy-grail. I don't know what is that but I myself find running after something which I'm not able to attain. It might sound funny, this might look nonsense and some people might allege me that I'm a 'psycho'. But this is what I'm. And BTW who have never been a psycho??? Everyone possesses psychological characters - when the character sums up something like E=MC2 then the same psychic character ends up being a genius character and when it dives into a black hole it just remains psychological problems.

I've always been been an excellent performer. From the times I remember, I've been always praised for something good inside me. This, initially, encouraged me to perform better. My life was built upon the expectations of other. The pressure built up, and I needed to outperform myself. My big brother always performed below par and whenever he did something better than what he used to, he was always praised for. If I did the same task, it was a normal task.

When I look back and see that the expectation of people let me run after something which was never there. I didn't build up the habbit of smoking or even drinking beer (except a can or two in a year or so) or anything which is considered to be socially bad. Now I feel that I was not praised but I was pushed into some kind of self destruction. The aim to outperform myself pushed me into lack of confidence. Whatever I did that was too obvious and nothing new. Now at this time whatever I do, that is something obvious to myself. The world that pushed me into this kind of feeling is no more with me and I'm left alone just to struggle with myself. It took me a while to realize, a second 'while' to accept, and then again a third 'while' to write down that yes I've been very inconsistent, unstable and uncertain.

If I make a list of my inconsistent habbits, it will be a moderate sized novel. I couldn't continue my study back then when I was in Kathmandu, and then again in Damak. My academic performance was outstanding. But I couldn't continue in what I was best in. I was a very good badminton player. I still remember the day when a few class mates (Aadesh, Surya, and Aashish) from Itahari, Sunsari asked me to join to play badminton on the Police Station courtyard. I remember the day when I bought the racket from the money my father gave me to buy books. I remember that day when on a chilling December day, my racket broke down and I couldn't control my tears. And yes I do remember the day when, within the first few months of learning badmintion I grabbed the second position in badmintion in Annual Sports Week. I was in the 7th Grade at that time. And after that year I grabbed the golden medal for five years in a row. But I could never developed myself as a professional player. I never even thought of a regular practice. It came to me just like a beautiful butterfly in a park, I played with it for sometimes and finally let it go.

My friends always called me a creative person, I like to call myself as a life-hobbiyst who likes to play with the ups and downs of life. I have seen many ups and downs in my life. I've been to place where no one might have been, I've done things which nobody might have done. I went on playing with my life and then people started calling it being creative. There were opportunities on the road and I let them go by playing for a while without giving serious attention just like a beautiful scenery passes by on the way - you see it, admire it, enjoy for a while but you don't take anything with you other than a fascinating experience.

I had a Yahoo 360 account back in Nepal where I used to jot down my daily activities - just like a diary. But after continuing it for couple of months, I left it. When I look back at everything that happened in between when I wrote the last 360 post and the post I'm writing right now, I wished I had continued writing about my daily life. A lot of things have changed since when I started running after the holy-grail but one thing that has remained the same is my unstability. The friends that studied with me have left me behind but yet I'm running experiencing with my life time and again. I did job when I was supposed to laugh and play, I went to remote places working as Computer Administrator, I worked as a teacher, I worked as a UN volunteer. But nothing pushed my further. I'm just at the place where I started!

I start something with a great interest and gradually my interest goes downwards and then I finally end up leaving it orphaned. I started singing, I composed about 7-8 songs, I played music and but yet I never feel confidence in being something professional. I started designing web sites, I learned HTML, CSS, MYSQL, PHP, Flash and all other things and developed a couple of sites and published them but yet I don't feel being professional. The list of my inconsistent activities is very long and I don't even remember all of them. Let me put down whatever I can remember:

I wanted to be a Civil Engineer but let it go by as soon as I passed 10th Grade and instead of joining science I joined commerce.

I composed songs, sang in festivals, did a concert in Abu Khaireni and let it go by.

I was very good at playing badmintion, and then let it go by.

Me and Manoj Dorji Sir decided to build a web site based on SLC exams, started it and then let it go by.

Me, Saroj, and Bibek formed ABSolute group, started working on hamrocyber.com and then let it go by.

I dropped my studies at Kathmandu when I was a University Topper.

I resigned from the Computer Administrator job in Basantapur, Terhathum, and joined LWFBRP.

Me, and Laxman Sir formed a Creative Eyes Group, developed a web site hotjhapa.com and after a year we let it go by.

I joined UNHCR and have to leave the job when I got the visa for USA.

I joined Trent in BoiseUbuntu group, but despite everyone's interest we let it go by.

I set up a blog QuickTweaks.com and although it was gaining some popularity, I couldn't hold my inconsistency.

Right now I'm working on a Twitter Web App and also designing another web site but I don't know whether I gonna finish them or not.

And today I thought to write something about my inconsistency and so set up this blog. I don't know where this will go and how far will this go. But one thing is sure I'm not going to give up. I just need a spark of fire to light up everything.

Many say I'm just one to try. I say I'm one less to quit.

As I said I like to experience with my life, and I'm such kind of guy who likes to learn something new everyday. I've been very lazy to write down whatever I see or learn in my life. I hope I can continue writing about the things that I stumble upon everyday.

Believe you can and you are halfway there.

Let me do it then!

item.title: 14 hours of non-stop action
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I love the life when it gets busy because it takes our mind away from all the tensions sorrounding it but it is not a fun when the life gets busy for continuous 14 hours!

Friday is usually my busy day. It is not used to be that busy at the start of the semester but as soon as I started tutoring DilliRam and Adrian,  life just got busier. Calc class was no fun at all. I hate all those convergence and divergence. I think the professor wasn't comfortable with proving the Power Series as we was messing up with the variables. Ethics in Computer Science class immediately followed. Almost all of the classmates love to talk in the class sharing their feelings and experiences about copyright issues. The only other I know who don't enjoy the class that much is Jane. I had a laptop with me so I just worked on a couple of PHP codes for the site I'm working on. I have an hour break in between this class and Math 187 class. I usually go back to my apartment for taking some rest but I was no mood in coming back. One of the reason being the cold weather. Yes, it is already summer but when the wind blows, you need a sweat shirt in Boise; one of the few reasons for hating Boise.

I planned to go McDonalds for not so healthy McChickens but I Nikhil called me from his apartment. His apartment is just on the top of the apartment where I lived during the first semester, Spring 2008. He prepared to heat burritos and made a glass of lassi. I enjoyed drinking lassi but burritos weren't cooked nicely, so I just dumped them. We talked for a while, have some fun cracking jokes on each other and I left for Math 187 class.

I didn't expect to see Dr. Kenny, my Math 187 professor, in the class. He told on Wednesday that his father is being diagnoised and is going under treatment and would not come today. He did say that he is going to send a substitute for today. This is one of the many things I like about the US education system. Professors usually don't miss a class and also they never ever come late to class. This is opposite from the system prevailed in Nepal. May be this is why US has developed a lot. Education is really a backbone of development.

My informal tutoring with Dilliram starts at 3:00pm and my Math 187 class ends at 2:30pm. Me, Garry, and Marlin stayed in the class for some minutes. Actually I was just a listener; Garry was talking about his recent crash with his apartment owner.

Dilliram recently sent his laptop to his brother who is workin in Oregon Dairy Farm and so he is looking for a laptop since last Friday. We did a quick search but there was not a good deal available so Dilliram left. The tutoring for Adrian starts at 7:00pm but, again, I was no mood in returning back to my apartment so I decided to stay at the Onyx lab working on the web site. I was very hungry so decided to give a second try to McDonald's visit.

Two guys were on queue before me, the one at the counter greeted both of them with "Hey! How r ya?" but for some 'strange' reason he was in no mood of greeting me. May be he was tired as I was. I ordered for two McChickens and 3 piece chicken select. Last time when I had chicken select, it was pretty cold and I don't enjoy eating them cold. Today they did the same thing. I don't usually complain against what I get but I thought to make them pay for not wishing me (ahem... ahem...). The manager asked me to wait for seven minutes but as I was eating McChickens, he immediately came with another packet. It was warmer than before but still not that hot. I let it go by.

As I was enjoying my food, I was watching CNN on the big screen on the left. The runner up of Miss US 2009, Carrie Prejean, who is in a big controversy because of her open criticism against same sex marriage, was on the show. After some commercial break, I heard something that really amazed me - contract marriage!!! From what I understoo contract marrige is an agreement between to-be married husband and wife where they agree on getting together for atleast the years they have agreed upon. I don't know where the world is going even the marriage has been commercialized now - kinda!

I love doing Java stuffs. Though it has been 3-4 years I'm playing with Java, I know getting used to with what it is meant to be Object Oriented and how elegance it looks when you follow the proper notion of OOP structure. Adrian had an assignment due on Wednesday. They have been given to design a GUI based contact manager. The instructor has provided some incomplete files but there were good enough to make me think about it and inspired me to code it 'correctly'. Tutoring has helped a lot to prosper my own knowledge.

When I got back I was really tired. Adrian gave me a ride upto my apartment and so I had to put my bick on his truck's trunk. As I'm writing this I'm feeling like I'm just finished climbing a big mountain but still I'm not done for today. I've not eaten anything. My stomach is paining a bit.

The most important job remained for today is to call back home as today is Mata Tirtha Aunsi (something similar to Mother's Day but it is more religious). I guess all of my roommates have called back home. I need to buy some credits online for calling back home. Usually the connection is bad and you spend half of the credits just to get connected. A big discouragement for someone who wants to call back home but certainly big encouragement for someone not to call back home when he is freaking tired!

item.title: Ubuntu 8.10 hits beta; the look lets the fans down again
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ubuntu 8.10 intrepid Ibex beta hit the market today but its appearance ONCE AGAIN came as a great disappointment. Since this is a beta version, we can't expect any change in the features now. All the works, which will be done until the final version hits the market on 30th October, will be only to fix the bugs. So, just keep your finger corssed until Jaunty Jackalope is released. If you are disappointed with the current appearance of your favorite Linux distro, here are some ways to give it a new fancy life again.

Everything is right about Ubuntu expect its look.  Changing its appearance is one of the highly requested features by many fans around the world. Fans were expecting a change with Hardy Heron, but it didn't happen. They had a lot of expectations with Intrepid Ibex but it came with nothing more than small color changes and this non-sense wallpaper:

[caption id="attachment_76" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption="The ugliest wallpaper ever"][/caption]

If you hate Ubunut's default appearance, here are some ways to make it look best of the all OSes

  • Install Emerald Theme manager and download emerald themes from gnome-look.org. I'm using Scaled_Black_Mod
  • Get rid of the bottom panel and replace it with some beautiful and productive dock. Here is a nice tutorial on how to do this.
  • Get mails, weather, and system info right on your desktop with conky. After this 'beauty' comes as a bonus for you. Read my previous post on how to do this. I've included all the required files and fonts so it shoudn't take you more than 10minutes.
  • Download Ubuntu wallpapers to show your Ubuntu love. If you love nature and prefer some natural backgrounds instead, you can get them from devian art. Other place to look for the beautiful wallpapers are: InterfaceLIFT, and StudioTwentyEight
  • If you want to get rid of the top menu, you can replace it with a nice looking cirular application menu.

[ad]

After a couple of hours your ugly desktop should more beautiful then mine:

[caption id="attachment_36" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Desktop Screenshot with conky, AWN, Scaled Black mod theme, and Gnome-Do"][/caption]

Let's hope Jackalope comes in a new look.
If you have a beautiful looking desktop, share with us. Shoot an email to admin[at]quickktweaks[dot]com with the screenshot(s) of your desktop. Beautiful ones will get published.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When is this "Prettier than OSX" supposed to happen?

At some point the developers have to sit back and think, no one is going to use something that looks like crap. Yes I love using it because I think its a wonderful operating system, but the average Joe isn't going to be interested.
Its like buying a car, sure I want a car that runs good, but I'm not going to buy the ugliest car(not that you have to pay for Ubuntu). Furthermore there have been some beautiful examples drawn up and submitted to ubuntu. Any of them would be 10 -1 better than what we have. When they update its appearance, do you think you will like every aspect of it? Or will you customize it to suit your tastes better?
It seems like you are already doing that, so rather than additional features and other UI enhancements, you are asking them to spend time on changes to the appearance that you probably won't completely agree with anyways.

item.title: A Ubuntu developer asks a user to dump Ubuntu for his idea
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
While skimming through the ideas listed on Ubuntu brainstorm site, I stumbled upon this idea today. A user, nandersson, thinks that a packager shouldn't be the only one giving attention towards bugs and they shouldn't be the only one to consider the ideas that the Ubuntu community suggests for a software. He suggests that the main developer of the software should draw their attention too and should try to consider the ideas. In response to this idea an anonymous developer writes:

[ad]

Developer comments Whoever said that packagers were not real developers? Packaging takes a lot longer than 5 minutes. Packages that are done in 5 minutes certainly don't get approved, as they're usually buggy and wrong. Most of the time, reporting a bug / feature request in the upstream bug tracker will get it to be fixed more quickly. Of course, you're free to use the brainstorm for this if you like - it just may not be as effective. Also, it's not a requirement that Core Devs have commit access upstream. And if you don't want to use whatever a developer has worked on, then you'd better stop using Ubuntu. Please remember to follow the code of conduct, at http://www.ubuntu.com/community/conduct/

Well, I personally believe that this is what happens when you give so much priority to one thing, become a brand loyal, and go crazy after it. It doesn't make sense for a developer to suggest (or threaten or whatever) a loyal user to dump Ubuntu. He'd better said "In Open Source world there are always alternative software which you can use instead of the one which you think the developers don't pay much attention to."

[ad]

From: http://brainstorm.ubuntu.com/idea/14123/

item.title: Install OpenOffice 3.0 Final in Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
[ad]

[Updated: .deb packages also started showing up] OpenOffice 3.0 Final is all set to be officially released on Monday, October 13 but it has already been uploaded to many servers worldwide. As of this writing there is no .deb package available. If you can't wait a couple of more days to get it installed in your Ubuntu box, here is a quick way to install it.

update: .deb packages started showing up. Install OpenOffice 3.0 final by issuing:

wget http://openofficeorg.secsup.org/stable/3.0.0/OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US_deb.tar.gz

tar -xvzf OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US_deb.tar.gz

cd OOO300_m9_native_packed-1_en-US.9358/DEBS/

sudo dpkg -i *.deb

That's it!

1. Get the file. Either download it manually or get it from your Terminal window. OpenOffice 3.0 has been uploaded to different servers, you can find it in .../stable/3.0.0/ folder. You can get it by issuing one of the following commands:

[ad]

wget http://openoffice.mirror.wrpn.net/stable/3.0.0/OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US.tar.gz

OR

wget http://mirrors.isc.org/pub/openoffice/stable/3.0.0/OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US.tar.gz

OR

http://ftp.osuosl.org/pub/openoffice/stable/3.0.0/OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US.tar.gz

OR

ftp://ftp.osuosl.org/pub/openoffice/stable/3.0.0/OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US.tar.gz

<

p style="text-align: center;">

2. Untar it

tar -xvzf OOo_3.0.0_LinuxIntel_install_en-US.tar.gz

3. Get inside the folder

cd OOO300_m9_native_packed-1_en-US.9358/RPMS

4. As of this writing, .deb package was not available so you need to install alien

sudo apt-get install alien

5. Convert all rpms packages to debs

alien -k *.*

6. Install OpenOffice

[ad]

sudo dpkg -i *.deb

7. Now we need to add menu entries

cd desktop-integration

sudo dpkg -i *.deb

item.title: Mozilla released Firefox 3.1 Beta1. Try it now!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Mozilla just released Beta1 of Firefox 3.1 browser. They haven't yet made the official announcement though.

The noticeable features include Ctrl+Tab 3D navigation browser, faster JavaScript performance, and Open a New Tab button just like Internet Explorer 7.

[caption id="attachment_194" align="aligncenter" width="500" caption="Ctrl+Tab 3D navigation browser is a welcome feature"][/caption]

If you want to give a try, here is how to install it in Linux:

wget ftp://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/firefox/releases/3.1b1/linux-i686/en-US/firefox-3.1b1.tar.bz2Update: From the official What's New page:

  • Web standards improvements in the Gecko layout engine
  • Added support for CSS 2.1 and CSS 3 properties
  • A new tab-switching shortcut that shows previews of the tab you're switching to
  • Improved control over the Smart Location Bar using special characters to restrict your search
  • Support for new web technologies such as the <video> and <audio> elements, the W3C Geolocation API, JavaScript query selectors, web worker threads, SVG transforms and offline applications.

    • Don't forget to backup your profile so that you can restore if something goes wrong.

    [caption id="attachment_193" align="aligncenter" width="382" caption="Open a new tab button"][/caption]

    $ tar -xvf firefox-3.1b1.tar.bz2

    $ cd firefox

    $ ./firefox

item.title: Intrepid Ibex to be Bundled with Two More System Tools
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Canonical, the distributor of Ubuntu OS, is often blamed for not listening the community such as ignoring the request for changing/improving default appearance. But not this time. Ever since they launched brainstorm.ubuntu.com, they have been very responsive about what the Ubuntu fans want. As a result of this Intrepid Ibex, which is due to release on 30th of this month, will be packed with two very useful system tools:

[ad]

Just few days ago, I wrote a post on making a live Ubuntu usb disk in three easy steps. Integrating a live USB maker tool into Ubuntu default installation has been one of the popular requests on brainstorm site.

[caption id="attachment_232" align="alignright" width="224" caption="USBLive Ubuntu"][/caption]

A new application USBLive has started showing up in Ibex beta. As you might have guessed, this handy tool helps you to make pizza. Just kidding! Of course, it allows you to make a USB bootable disk with Ubuntu in it. Just give the source image (.iso) file or insert a live CD, plug-in your USB drive, adjust the space to be reserved by the default installation, and click Make Startup Disk. How easy as that? You can access USBLive from System>Administration>Create Startup Disk menu

[ad]

Another system tool that has been included is System Cleaner. It cleans up your system to make it

[caption id="attachment_233" align="alignright" width="280" caption="System Cleaner"][/caption]

'kinda-new'. You can clean all the installed applications or select only those which you are not going to use any more. Access System Cleaner from Applications>System Tools>System Cleaner menu At first, you might think removing the applications can already be done with Add/Remove tool. So, what's the difference? Nothing! It just gives you a list of those applications which you have installed after running up Ubuntu for the first time. No confusions whatsoever. It comes very handy when, for an example, you don't want to poke the default applications but only want to remove those non-sense applications which you gave try few days ago. BTW, if you want to track all you apt activities, the ever useful tapt is always there.

item.title: Spyglass for Windows
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Spyglass is probably the most beautiful Windows disk space analyzer you'll ever see. - Lifehacker
Powerful Scanning Engine; Elegant Interface; Simple Usage; Effective Duplicate Finder - addictivetips.com
Spyglass is a nice software and provides features of two different programs in a single software. - ilovefreesoftware.com

Powerful. Beautiful. Simple.

We made Spyglass to be simple and beautiful on the outside, but powerful and reliable on the inside; we wanted a tool that we would love to open everyday and admire for its simplicity, beauty, practicality, and power.  The result is Spyglass.  Spyglass is a perfect companion for fixing your cluttered disks and folders.  It allows you to navigate your folders and files using a beautiful Sunburst View, a versatile File Navigation View, and smart Breadcrumbs.  Spyglass also comes with a powerful Duplicate Finder that finds duplicate files based on the contents of the files, regardless of how they are named.  All of these useful features are wrapped in an intuitive and beautiful user interface.  Drag and drop a folder on, or simply click the center icon to start scanning.  Getting help is always just one click away.  And with Windows Explorer integration, you can browse any file or folder quickly and easily.  You will love the simplicity and power of this amazing tool.

Intuitive Navigation

The beautiful Sunburst View, the versatile File Navigation Bar, and the smart Breadcrumbs allow you to easily navigate your files and folders.  On the Sunburst View, click the blue arcs to drill in and the center black circle to drill out.  You can see the details about a file or a folder by hovering your mouse over an arc.  The blue arcs represent folders, the orange arcs represent files, and the gray arcs are combined files and folders that are very small.  The File Navigation Bar on the left shows all the files and folders in a tree structure.  Select a folder or a file to highlight the corresponding arc on the Sunburst View.  Click anywhere outside to unhighlight an arc.  You can also double click a folder to drill in and double click it again to drill back out.  The Breadcrumbs on the top show you the full path of the selected folder.  You can click any folder within the Breadcrumbs to drill in to that folder.

Duplicate Finder

Spyglass is not just for visualizing your hard disk, but is also a tool to keep it clean and spacious.  Spyglass comes with a fast and reliable Duplicate Finder that is very easy to use.  It works by analyzing the content of the files, not just the names, giving you more accurate results.  After you have flagged files, you can either choose to relocate the files or remove them – sending the files to their new home, the Recycle Bin.  Select a file on the left panel to see all of its duplicates.  On the right panel, the first file is the file that you have selected, the others are its duplicates.  Now, flag files red for removal or yellow for relocation by clicking the flag icon.  The first click flags it red, the second click flags it yellow, and the third deselects the file.  Once you have flagged the files, use the bottom buttons to either show, move, or delete the flagged files.  It has never been so easy to find duplicate files, and move or delete them.

Browse using Windows Explorer

Want to perform regular file and folder operations?  Opening Windows Explorer is just one click away.  When in Visualization mode or Duplicate Finder mode, you will see a curled arrow in front of a file or a folder.  Click the arrow to open and highlight the selected file or folder in the Windows Explorer.

item.title: Being on LifeHacker's #4
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday I slept late night working (that was about 18 hours of work in a day!!!). I called home and talked with my parents. It has been a long time I've not talked with them. I wish I did it a couple of times when I was really down. I missed my home, friends and everything there.

Raju was here when I was still in the bed. After taking a shower we sat for some talks, he is impressed with the upcoming site. Today I got busy with translating stuffs and most importantly one small piece of validation - validating departure date, return date, and trip. In the site I'm designing I needed to check whether the user has selected round trip or one way trip. If the user selects round trip then there must be returning date and the departing date should be less than returning date. My first thought was that it gonna be very easy with couple of validators but yesterday night I stuck with it for about half and an hour and today for about an hour. Finally, I gave up using symonfy's inbuilt validators and created my own.

Dilliram called me and I went to library to help with his programming assignment. He and Adrian are in the same class so I just explained him the codes I've written yesterday for Adrian. Raju was here almost whole day and he had dinner with us. Anita has been waiting for a week for coding her Boggle game. I'm pretty tired and it is not a good idea to sit coding a program that needs an extensive recursion when you are mentally down. But as I had to do some laundry, we went together with our laptops to the Community Hall to give Boggle a try. No success so we returned back. She is already ready with her next assignment!

But the big news for today is that my post on conky setup(Gmail+Weather+Beauty right on your Ubuntu desktop) which was published last year grabbed #4 position on LifeHacker's top 10 downloads for Ubuntu. The post on conky setup has been an evergreen hit. It made to the Digg's front page and well over 150 comments, and about 50 pingbacks, LifeHacker itself posted a post on my post (no pun intended). Also, I'm receiving a constantly about 1000 visits per day mostly because of that post. And the most interest of all here is what LifeHacker wrote:

This one's an old-school app, controlled entirely by text files, but the results can be brilliant, as evidenced by one hacker's mutli-colored, iconic desktop, or a setup for fans of to-dos and Twitter replies. Best of all, you can mix and match the features and data you want displayed in any setup, as we showed you in our Conky guide. Basically, Conky can put any data you want, from your desktop or the web, on your desktop, and keep it updated, and that's a great thing.

Me Hacker??!! I don't mind ;-)

item.title: Missed Jeff Line but listened David Heinemeier
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I didn't want to go to my calc class today as I was feeling very lazy waking up. But I've already missed enough of the classes and I'm lagging behind by a huge margin. The test is on coming Friday so I collect some energy to get myself out of the bed. Today's calc class was informative and should help me lot in my test.

Because of being busy with all other stuffs, I hardly get any time to do my assignments. I've taken procrastination to a new level - my assignment was due at 1:30pm and I sat down to do it at 11:00am. And the interesting part is the assignment was on math 187. Sometimes I belive that I'm a bit crazy.

As I was just starting to do my assignment, Teresa Cole, my cs253 professor, sent us an email:

Jeff Line from Cypress Semiconductor is going to be talking about using C with embedded systems today in class. Sorry about the short notice for those of you who don't come to class.

I'm one of them who don't go to cs253 class. I wanted to go but I also needed to do my assignment.

Me along with Garray, Marlin and Taylor had already worked on all the problems from assignment last week and I had roughly written down all the stuffs so it didn't take long to finish it off. As I was surfing some random internet (yes there are two types of internet - regular and random. regular internet is the internet which you surf for some specific purpose such as reading and responding emails, reading news etc and random internet is the internet which you surf when you have enough time and nothing else to do), I stumbled upon a presentation video by David Heinemeier. He is the guy who developed Ruby on Rails (RoR). His presentation was not on RoR but on The Secret to Making Money Online. He made some valid points so couldn't resist myself watching 32 minutes video.

One of the many things I liked about David's presentation was that we shouldn't always focus on damn big business. Starting with a small one and go on building the community/customers is a way to go. This way we might make less money but we also take less risk. Making another YouTube, Facebook or MySpace could be a huge risk and the odds of making it a big hit is 1:100000 whereas the odds of coming with something new and making it a success is 1:1000. I totally agree with him.

Finally answering one of the questions from listeners, he says that working 13-14 hours a day as a programmer is just a waste of time and is very unproductive. A good 2-3 hours will be more than enough to get your creative production out; more work doesn't guarantees quality. Though I missed Jeff Line and I'm sure he might have given some damn good lecture but at least I learned something good today listening David.

Its about half past six right now, my job at the library starts at 7pm and I'm waiting for my turn and writing this blog.

item.title: Learning Extravaganza!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Back in my country I plugged-in my telephone cable into 56KB internal modem, and after hearing the dialing tone for a while I was on to the internet with a connection speed of about 20KB/Sec. Imagine the experience of browsing the internet - it was damn slow. On top of that the internet itself is very expensive and again put the telephone's charge on top of the that. Whew! Everytime your eyes will be at the total connection time. The telephone charge after 10PM is low - 1 call will be counted for 8 minutes; compare that with 2 min per call during day time. So, you will be lured to wait until your wall-clock hits 10:10pm. The extra ten minutes was to make sure your wall-clock is not giving you the wrong time. Why take risk?

After coming to US, the internet is almost free and is extremely fast. Some people complain that it is still extremely slow but for the one who has only seen a drop of water, a river is almost an ocean. The speed has changed and the time I browse the internet has changed but the one thing that remained same is my thirst for collecting information and habit of learning something new. Once I talked to my best friend Pankaj about Nepalese young generation not being able to exploit the internet for good. Yahoo messenger, cybernepal.com, and hi5 seemed to be enough for them and I'm still convinced that they are still on the same trunk, and nothing has changed. I'm happy that even when my heart was pounding along with every tick of the wall-clock, I never abondoned my hunger for learning something new.Here in the US some people specially Dilliram, and some library patrons wonder and ask me "How did you do that? Where did you learn that?" Only I know how hard I've tried to gain the knowledge.

The one difference between browsing habit in my country and over here in US is the ratio of browsing time to the amount of knowledge I gain. As internet is too fast, I find myself browsing internet insanely. I don't have to care about the connection time and neither I've to worry about telephone bills. So, the browsing hours couldn't be as productive as it used to be in Nepal.I sometimes browse YouTube, repeteadly browse digg.com, nettuts.com, and lifehacker.com. Though I still learn something new from there but heck I hate browsing non-sense articles but it is also true that I can't help myself.

Yesterday was a great day regarding the amount of information I learned and thanks for everyone's darling - Internet. As I was curious about upcoming Symfony 2 features, I stumbled upon Dependency Injector. I''ve heard about Dependency Injector a couple of times when Fabien Potencier, the lead developer and founder of Symfony, talked about it on his website (http://fabien.potencier.com). But I didn't give much attention to it because I always grew a kind of 'not for me' feeling. Yesterday I thought to give it a try and hey it is freaking simple and awesome. I didn't know that I was already using Dependency Injector without realizing it. Fabien's examples were dead simple and easy to understand English. I've read his book on Symfony and other articles and I'm very impressed of his writing style. He writes in pretty plain English, and with lots of examples so a non-native speaker like me can easily grasp the main idea. It could be because he himself is a non-native English speaker.After reading his three posts on Dependency Injector, I moved on looking for some more advance concepts and Google is everyone's friend.

I was supposed to finish Adrian's project. I did half of it last Friday and half of it was pending. Though most of the codes were already done but I still call it half because the remaining portion was the most difficult one - sorting, comparator, file reading and writing. I don't believe that it took me about 2 hours to finish everything. As I said in my earlier post, I learn everything new when I'm doing Adrian's/ Dilliram's assignment. And it was no exception this time. I cleared myself on the concept of Comparator and Comparable and learned how to effectively pass one Comparable to another class. Hey! Was I injecting a dependency object? I don't know becuase I'm not an expert.

Back to home and lots of personal stuffs pending, most importantly my calc 2 exam is coming closer and it has been long since I've done any assignments becuase I understood nothing about convergence and divergence in the class. Again Internet to the rescue. I wanted to look for some online tutorials and probably vides. This time I didn't have to worry too much for finding the relevant stuffs as I knew http://www.justmathtutoring.com has got it all. Patrick, the guy who works on few examples is simply awesome. He, just like Fabien, talks simple English, shows some tricks to remember, and warns about pitfalls. I spent rest of the night watching his videos on series and sequence.

Oh boy! that was really a learning extravaganza! You are awesome, Internet!!

item.title: Getting ready for a Google Wave extension
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We released beta version of tweat.org about 10 days ago. As me and Trent were having conversation in Google Wave (the first day I got an invitation from Brian), and planning for a meal to one of the best Indian Cuisine that I know of, we felt a need for tweat app for Google Wave. When it comes coding something new, the 'coding-monkey' inside me starts jumping. I immediately jumped into reading documentation. As Google Wave is still in very early stages, there are not too many resources available. The official Google Wave Extension documentation is pretty good and covers almost everything required to pull out your first Google Wave extension.

First I was confused on which extension should I choose - gadgets or robots? Personally I feel that a gadget is pretty much limited on what it can do, while robot seems to be more powerful (also you will create more whirls in your friends' circle if you can say - "I've created a Robot for Google Wave"). But as soon as I learned that I've to learn a whole new framework to crate a new robot, I paused. To code a robot you should be familiar with either Python or Java Servlets. Notice my use of 'framework' here. Java is not new to me - being a Computer Science student, I've been taking Java for about 2 years in a row and I absolutely love Java. But I don't have any experience regarding the web-server side of Java. I've been thinking to learn a different language or at least a better tool for a change and have been considering Groovy for a while. Grails framework seems an excellent tool for web development in Groovy. It couldn't be a better chance (and challenge?) for me to learn Groovy/Grails than this time. I've already installed Groovy/Grails and already compiled and run my first 'Hello, World!' program. IBM developers works web site has got some really useful tutorials on Grails. In fact they got a whole series on it. Though I found that it is kind-of outdated for the latest version of Grails, it is still a very good starting point.

Learning a new language or tool is not bad but designing a publicly accessible piece of software using a tool/language in which you are not experienced with is a bad practice. So, I've decided not to code anything right now using Groovy/Grails/Java or Python for now. I will stick with PHP in which I'm pretty much comfortable with. This means no coding for Tweatbot for Google Wave right now. This doesn't mean I've completely given up - NO! It won't be too long before I'll post another article covering few glitches with Grails/Groovy/Java. As I already said, I'm reading the tutorials so I should be ready to go for it in about a month. This also doesn't mean there will be no Tweat extensions for Google Wave. I'm just thinking of getting a gadget out first to see how it works. It might also boost my confidence. It doesn't seem too difficult to code a gadget. I might probably writing a tutorial to share my experience so stay updated!

item.title: Me as a Pragmatic Programmer
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I've finished reading the first chapter of The Pragmatic Programmer yesterday. A whole bunch of developers/users at stackoverflow.com recommended this book as one of the must read book for a programmer. After ordering the book through my university library, I started reading it few days ago. The book is awesome, and really informative. It is written in simple English so even someone whose first language is not English (like me) can digest the content easily. But please be aware that this post is not a review of the book. I've never done any review of a book (I will come to the main reason on why). I just wanted to compare myself with the few qualities of a  pragmatic programmer the books talks about in the first few pages, esp. in Preface section.

The authors - Andrew Hunt and David Thomas, have composed this book in a way that they take a metaphor and go on describing the metaphor and relate that with a programming workplace environment. Finally, they summarize everything they have discussed under the metaphor with a tip. So, basically only remembering the tip will be good enough for you to check yourself if ever you forget the qualities of a pragmatic programmer. That's why the authors have even provided a quick reference card. You can paste it on the wall just above where your computer screen  is and follow a pragmatic programmer's good practice everyday.

The book starts with chapter entitled - A Pragmatic Philosophy but even before that it (in preface section) it gives you two really important tips and talks about what makes a Pragmatic Programmer:

Early adopter/fast adapter

Am I? Yes, I am an early adopter of technology. It might not relate with my programming world but whenever something comes out, even if it is in alpha version, I download it, install it and try to get a good knowledge of it. Talk about alpha version of different Linux distributions, talk about browsers, talk about IDEs, talk about Google's Gmail, Google Voice, Google Wave etc. I've been an early adopter of all these.

Inquisitive

Am I? Well, the answer will be both yes and no. I am known in the class and within my classmates for not asking too many questions. I'm a good listener. But it doesn't mean that I implement whatever those speakers say. And yes I'm an inquisitive person too because I ask questions to myself, I get curious when I see something on how that might have been implemented? Sometimes this waste my time too much as I go on inquiring something, I get into too much details.

Critical Thinker

Honestly, No, I'm not! I don't like to challenge other because I feel they are right in their own views. Again, it doesn't mean I try to implement what other people say but I don't rip apart other's ideas and views. I do propose my own ideas and views on a particular problem, but I can never resist myself from saying 'OK' even if I don't like the idea. This is the main reason why I'm not being able to review a book till now. I hope to improve on this one. Should I start with this book itself?

Realistic

Given the availability of time, yes I'm. I do try to understand the underlying nature of each problems. One thing good of me is if you throw me any problem, I will reach to the solution sooner or later. To achieve solutions for each problem you face, you have to understand the nature of each problem.

Jack of all trades

This is my favorite one. Before reading the book I always felt bad for trying (read: being forced by the nature of programming world) to be jack of all trades. The book suggests you to be jack of all trades and I agree (and feel better). As I talked earlier under Early adopter/fast adapter, I do try to learn as soon as something comes out and I believe this is necessary. Unless you go on establishing your own Microsoft or Google, you probably will be working for other companies, and you can never know in which environment you will be working. It could be a company that specializes web development, or could be a company specializing in system software. If you are already familiar with all the options you have, you will have so many choices when it comes choosing a job, and moving forward.

This is not an exhaustive list of all the good qualities/principles that the book talk about, as I go on reading the book, I will try to compare myself with the pragmatic programmer the book talks about. I will come with another post comparing myself and all the practices that I follow with the qualities that the book talks about pretty soon!

item.title: Install Bulky Linux Distribution Without Burning a CD
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This tutorial is about installing Fedora Linux without burning a CD/DVD.

Scenario/ Assumption: 1) You have Microsoft Windows 2) You have your system drive as C: (No matter whether it is FAT or NTFS) 3) You have Fedora .ISO files in the root directory of some partition (the partition must be FAT!) 4) You need to have a program that can open up the .ISO files. You can use free file archiver. 7zip works great. In this tutorial I am using Winrar. [ad]

Steps:

  1. Go to C: drive and create a directory; name it boot
  2. Open the .ISO file with Winrar. Inside isolinux directory, you will find two files: initrd.img and vmlinuz. Extract these two files to boot directory you have created in step 1 above
  3. Go to http://sourceforge.net/projects/grub4dos to download grub4dos. This is required to boot grub from dos.
  4. Extract the contents of grub4dos. Rename the directory to grub and copy it inside boot directory.
  5. Inside the grub directory, you will find two files; grldr and grldr.mbr. Copy these two files to your C: root directory
  6. Open boot.ini file which contains the boot information for Windows. You need to enable Show Hidden Files and Show System Files to view it in C: root directory. The easiest way is to type C:boot.ini in the Run dialog box.
  7. Type C:grldr="Start GRUB" at the bottom of boot.ini and save it.
  8. Open menu.lst file with Notepad which is inside C:bootgrub directory and type the following lines at the bottom: title Install Fedora Linux kernel (hd0,0)/boot/vmlinuz initrd (hd0,0)/boot/initrd.img
  9. Save the menu.lst file and restart your computer.

[ad]

item.title: Disable Accidental Touchpad Tapping While Typing
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Often when you are typing, your thumb touches the touchpad and the typing start from another position. Follow these steps to disable accidental touchpad tapping: [ad]

  1. Enable SHMConfig in your xorg.conf file. Press Alt+F2. It will bring you the Run Application dialog box.
  2. Type following and hit enter: gksu gedit /etc/X11/xorg.conf
  3. It will ask you for your super user password. Give it!
  4. xorg.conf should open in gedit file editor
  5. Look for following lines: Section "InputDevice" Identifier "Synaptics Touchpad"... ... EndSection
  6. Add the following line just before the line EndSection Option "SHMConfig" "true"
  7. Save the file
  8. Open a Terminal
  9. Type the following command syndaemon -d -t -i 5 -d runs the command in background -t disables only tapping and scrolling but not mouse movements -i sets the idle time in seconds after the last key has been pressed. The default is 2 seconds. I was convenient with 5 secs. It means if I don't press any key for 5 secs, the touchpad will be enabled.

Now to run make the command as a startup command follow the following steps:

  1. Go to System>Preference>Sessions
  2. Click on Add button.
  3. Fill up the following data in the dialog box that appears: Name: { Name of the command such as: Disable Touchpad } Command: syndaemon -d -t -i 5 Comment: { Any comments such as: Disables touchpad's tapping functionality while typing }
  4. Click on OK and Close the Sessions dialog box

Enjoy tapping less typing ;-)

[ad]

item.title: Install MS Office 2007 in Linux
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For help, feedback, comments, and other discussions for this tutorial, please visit the official forum.

Though there are many alternatives for MS Office, no doubt MS Office 2007 is a winner. If you want to install MS 2007 in Linux follow these steps: [ad]

  1. Install Wine
  2. Select Applications>Wine>Configure Wine to bring the Wine Configuration dialog box.
  3. Select Windows Version as Windows Vista from the Applications Tab
  4. Override two dll files rpcrt4.dll and msxml3.dll from Libraries tab. Override them to be Native (Windows)
  5. Download rpcrt4.dll file. Click here and save it on your desktop.
  6. Open the c_drive from Wine menu
  7. Delete rpcrt4.dll and msxml3.dll files from Windows/System32 directory.
  8. Copy the downloaded rpcrt4.dll file into Windows/System32 directory
  9. Download msxml3.msi file from Microsoft download site (here is the direct link for your convenience).
  10. Install msxml3.msi file from the Terminal window by issuing msiexec /i msxml3.msi
  11. Double click on setup.exe file from your MS Office 2007 installation CD. If it doesn't work just type wine setup.exe from the Terminal window.
  12. Follow the normal installation procedures.

Watch the step-by-step video:

[youtube]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=crW8nWoEpmw[/youtube]

UPDATE: Before you install Office 2007 don't forget about winetricks. It might help to resolve many issues. Just go to http://www.kegel.com/wine/winetricks, copy the text (codes) in a file winetrick. From the terminal window type sh winetricks. Check all the msxml stuffs and click install.

[frameworkads ad="2"]

item.title: Video & Voice Chating in Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In this article I will show you how to make your webcam work in Ubuntu Linux 7.10 without even without opening the terminal window once. I pre-assume your microphone is working, if not leave a comment and then I will help you. You would have more pain to make your video work in Windows than in Ubuntu Linux.

Follow these easy steps (and ask your girlfriend to follow these steps too): [ad]

  1. Head to http://download.tuxfamily.org/arakhne/pool/ricoh-webcam-r5u870/2.6.22-14-generic/
  2. Click on the file ricoh-webcam-r5u870-2.6.22-14-generic_0.10.0-4_i386.deb
  3. In the dialog box that appears, select Open with GDebi Package Installer (it is default so you should be able only to click on OK button)
  4. In the package installer dialog box click Install Package. Done! Finished! But check if your webcam is working:
  5. Go to Applications menu (or just press Alt+F1 you lazy fellow)>Add Remove ...
  6. On the upper right list box labelled Show: ensure All available applications is selected
  7. In the search box type: xawtv and select and then install
  8. Go to Applications>Sound & Video>Xawtv. You should straightly see your face yourself. Want to show your face to your girlfriend and do chat simultaneously? Follow these steps
  9. Head to http://www.skype.com/download/skype/linux/choose/ and click on the link. Again the sametwo dialog boxes should appear. Install using the default option: Open with GDebi Package Installer and then clicking the Install Package on the second dialog box.
  10. Go to Applications>Internet>Skype and log in.

Assuming your girlfriend is already waiting you in Skype, call her and enable your video. That's all!

If you want to see your girlfriend's face, ask her to follow all the above steps. If she can't understand you talking so technically (for the first time in her life), send her a link to this blog. I swear I won't ask her email id. I swear!

item.title: Three Little Things To Make Your Ubuntu Desktop Beautiful and Productive
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
For help, feedback, comments, and other discussions for this tutorial, please visit the official forum.

How can you make your Ubuntu desktop look beautiful and be productive at the same time? With these three things:

[frameworkads ad="1"]

I. Avant Window Navigator: Avant Window Navigator (AWN) is a Mac like dock-bar which (as of now) sits horizontally on the bottom of your screen (development is on the way for vertical support) helping you to launch programs and locations. You can install applets to make it more productive such as checking email, reporting local weather, showing time and calendar etc. Let's get our hands dirty (to make the desktop beautiful)

Installing Avant Window Navigator:

1) Be sure your system supports Desktop Effects. I've seen people searching the internet for hours to find out - Why AWN doesn't even start? Try typing compiz in a Terminal window. What does the output say? If it says something like ...aborting and using fallback: /usr/bin/metacity then you are out of luck.

2) Get AWN. If you are using Gutsy then you need to enable Unsupported updates (gutsy-backports) in your software repository list. Go to System>Software Sources. And in the Updates tab check Unsupported updates (gutsy-backports) Close the dialog box to let Ubuntu update the repository list automatically. If you are using Hardy you don't need to do anything as AWN has now been included in universe/gnome repository.

Now you are ready to issue the following command: sudo apt-get install avant-window-navigator awn-manager

You should be now able to run AWN from Applications>Accessories menu but AWN doesn't look so much stylish and productive without the applets.

3) To install additional applets, add following two repositories to your software sources list (for both Hardy and Gutsy)

deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/reacocard-awn/ubuntu/ gutsy main deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/reacocard-awn/ubuntu/ gutsy main

As soon as Ubuntu finishes reloading the information of the software repositories, you will be ready to issue the following command: sudo apt-get install avant-window-navigator-bzr awn-core-applets-bzr awn-manager-bzr

4) Now to add applets to the dock bar, right click on the edge of the dock bar, click on preferences go to Applets tab and add your favorites applets.

II. GnomeDo

GonmeDo is a launcher similar to QuickSilver for Mac and Launchy for Windows which allows you to run/open the applications/location installed in your Gnome desktop with a couple of key strokes. It searches for the installed applications with a keystroke and then you can perform the general actions such as open/play/run etc. I promise you will forget about opening the run application dialog box. What I liked about GnomeDo is its ability to learn. Suppose, if you have installed Avant Window Navigator, aMSN and Amarok and you regularly use Amarok, hitting A will bring you Amarok but not other applications.

Installing GnomeDo

1) If you are using Gutsy you need to add two lines in your software sources list:

[frameworkads ad="1"]

deb http://ppa.launchpad.net/do-core/ubuntu gutsy main deb-src http://ppa.launchpad.net/do-core/ubuntu gutsy main

Hardy users are lazy (oops! I mean lucky)

2) Issue the following command to install GnomeDo: sudo apt-get install gnome-do

You should be now able to run GnomeDo from Applications>Accessories menu. Once it is started, you can launch it with a shortcut Super+Space

III. Beauty Tips Tweaks:

You are now ready with the 'productive' factor. For making your desktop look a little more beautiful, you need to tweak your system a bit:

1) Remove bottom pane You don't need it anymore. Remove it by right clicking on the pane and selecting Delete this panel

2) Enable top panel transparency: Enable transparency of top panel. R-click on the panel, select Properties. On the Background tab select Solid Color and set full transparency.9076321895604071

3) Enable 3D look and transparency of AWN

R-click on the edge, select Preferences: On the Task Appearance tab set: Text Color to White; Text Shadow Color to #1B3B12 and opacity to 225; Text Background color to Black and opacity to 37; Arrows Color to White and opacity to 102

On the Bar Appearance tab set: Look to 3D look; Tick Enable rounded corners; Bar angle to 45; Bar height to 48; Icon offset to 10; Main border Color to Black and opacity to 106; Internal border Color to White and opacity to 35; uncheck Show separator between launchers and tasks

On the Glass Engine tab set: Gradient First step color to #454545 and opacity to 29; Gradient Second step color to #010101 and opacity to 68; Both Highlight First step and Second step colors to White and opacity to 11

4) Download beautiful wallpapers from here http://www.studiotwentyeight.com/wallpapers.htm

 [frameworkads ad="2"]

For help, feedback, comments, and other discussions for this tutorial, please visit the official forum.

item.title: Customizing Your GRUB Screen
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Ever wanted to show your favorite image as your GRUB splash screen in Ubuntu something similar to other distros such as Fedora? Follow these steps: [ad]

  1. Get a picture and open it with GIMP.
  2. Go to Image>Mode>Indexed...
  3. Make the maximum no. of colors to 14. To do this, enter 14 in the box that shows the default value of 255.
  4. Click Convert
  5. Your image might not look that good, but GRUB screen can handle only 14 colors. If you don't like the 14 color picture at all, try changing the color to grayscale (Image>Mode>Grayscale). Some pictures look great in grayscale than in 14 colors.
  6. Go to Image>Scale Image...
  7. Set the width as 640 pixels and height as 480 pixels. You might need to click on the Chain icon to be able to set the exact size.
  8. Click Scale
  9. You have to save the file as a X PixMap image. Go to File>Save As... In the save dialog box Click on Select File Size (By Extension). From the drop down menu, select X PixMap image (third option from bottom). Give a filename, Save and close GIMP.Make the archive of the image:
  10. R-click on the the file you have just saved and select Create Archive...
  11. Give a name (the default should be okay). Don't forget the save the file type as .gz. From the extension menu select .gz.
  12. Click CreateCopy the archive file to /boot/grub/mygrubimages
  13. Those who know how to copy files using Terminal window can easily do that. For those who prefer graphical way of copying files should open the Run Dialog box (Alt+F2) and type: gksu nautilus /boot/grub/ and hit enter. If it asks for your password, give it.
  14. Create a new folder, name it mygrubimages (you can name it anything) and copy the archive file into it.
  15. Open /boot/grub/menu.lst. Again in the Run dialog box, type: gksu gedit /bott/grub/mnu.lst and hit enter. If it asks for password again then you know what to do - restart and use Windows Vista. It never nags you for doing any administrative tasks! ;-)
  16. In the file that opens, add a following line: splashimage=/boot/grub/mysplashimages/nameOfArchiveFile.gz
  17. Save the file, restart your Ubuntu box, and get ready to be welcomed by your favorite picture

item.title: Don't be evil, Google!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The latest fight between Google, and Microsoft is making me nervous. I use almost all of the Google services. I don't like what Google is doing with Microsoft, and how it's turning its face away from its "Don't Be Evil" and "Be Open" motto. Although I don't use any iOS devices -- except an iPad for reading books, I've always liked how Google makes all of its services, and products available for iOS platforms without any compromises. Making something like Google Now-like voice recognition for competing platforms had given me more confidence in trusting Google, and its products. Until now. This nervousness also means that I'm switching back to using my Android phone after using Windows Phone (Nokia Lumia 920) for more than 1 month. Among others, I depend too much on Google Voice for texting, and making calls so I cannot risk loosing it. If making people switch to Android from WP is what Google wanted, then it won this war, at least with me. But now this die-hard fan is less happy, and has less confidence in using Google products. May be depending on Google's products for everything was a bad idea. Next time, before trying out any of Google's alpha project, I will first consider trying out the alternatives.   [This post first appeared in my Google+ account: https://plus.google.com/102672078908622237427/posts/gnFARpRimCy]

item.title: To Succeed, Let Yourself Fall, and Fail
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I have this obsession of trying to do everything perfect right from the beginning. Ask me to implement something and you will find me first collecting at least 1 book, and few online resources on the subject before even starting a single line of code. The reason behind doing this is simple – I’m afraid of failing and I want to do everything properly right from the beginning. Researching, or reading about a subject matter beforehand is not wrong but making it too obsessive has its own drawbacks and will actually make you fail harder. I’ve been realizing about the drawbacks of this ‘obsessive failure restraint’ habit.
Trying to restrain myself from committing a mistake always gave me a false sense of perfectionism. I somehow grew up this wrong thinking that perfectionist means someone who never commits a mistake. Now, that I re-read stories of renowned people, like Steve Jobs, who are/ were no less than perfectionists, I’ve realized that they’ve failed more often but they learned from their mistakes. When you make small mistakes then you can see how you came to commit those mistakes, rectify them, learn from them, and will, probably, never make the same mistakes again. But if you fail big which will be, obviously, because of the small mistakes you were never aware of, it will be hard to find where those tiny mistakes were, and you can neither rectify them, nor you can learn from the mistakes. Probably, the failed project itself was a very good idea, and had a potential but you will end of giving up because of the smaller mistakes you were afraid to commit, and then admit.
For last few weekends I’ve been joining my few friends to go ice-skating, and skiing. I have never done ice-skating, or skiing before because, to be honest, I was afraid of falling down and ending up breaking my fingers, hands, or legs. But last weekend I decided to give it a try and see how it goes. Better to be late than to be never, I thought. In the group there were only 1, or 2 people who could call themselves an advanced skater. All of the others were starters, just like me. Some of them were even afraid of going for skating. At least I had some plus points on that regard. I thought I had better chance of learning faster because I was at least not afraid to enter the arena.
At the end of the day it turned out that my other friends had learned more than me. They could skate freely without any support, and they were skating at the center of the arena. I found myself taking help of the fence all the time, and could hardly skate freely for more 10-20 seconds. To make the experience worst, I fell so hard on the floor with my face down that I nearly had a concussion. My friends had to help me to get off the arena. I was afraid that the fear of falling down so hard would overcome me and I would never be able to skate again. So I decided to go back skating again after resting for about 10 minutes.
I’m still recovering from the pain of that hit. But the pain was nothing compared to the embarrassment of being the last of the lot. How could everyone started skating so quickly, and I ended up being at where I started? After a week, and after being last of the lot again, but this time with skiing, I’ve started to realize the reason of me being the last – I was too afraid of falling on the ground. All my skiing 101 friends ended up skiing from more advanced level slopes, but I ended up only skiing only on the bunny hills. I didn’t fell much but the last fall, which I tried from bunny slope++ level, was pretty cruel; nearly breaking my leg.
I hardly remember what happened after the moment I started falling when I was ice-skating. But I do remember that I was trying hard not to fall down. One of my friends had told me to lean forward, esp. when if I started losing my balance, so not to fall down. I took that advice too seriously because when I started losing my balance, I first struggled for few seconds to keep my balance, and then leaned forward too much. At that point I also had reached to the edge of the arena where the floor was very rough. My boot stuck, and I fell my face down. I now think that I could have avoided the injury if I had let myself down before trying too much to keep my balance. I should have committed that mistake to avoid the bigger injury. But I wanted to hold myself still, saving myself from the embarrassment of falling.
I fell for the last time that day again just before we left. The same friend who taught me to lean forward, saw me falling, and noticed what I was doing something wrong. He gave me some tips - “Don’t try to walk, let one foot glide you for few seconds before trying it again with the second foot”. I made some improvements right away after that. I was freely skating for more than 20-30 seconds. But it didn’t last because we had to leave the arena for ice-hokey practice game.
Later, when all of us got together, we talked about how everything went. I was surprised that, in an average, my other friends had fallen for about 10 times; 8 times more than me, which I was proud of then. How foolish I was trying so hard not to fall? They fell more than me and ended up learning more than me. I remember myself trying to be very close to the fence, so that I could catch it for support if I fell. Later on I found myself not able to skate without the fence support because it gave me so much security. Same thing happened with skiing yesterday. My friends fell more than I did. Their jackets, and trousers were wet because of snow. One friend complained about feeling too much pain in his right thumb. Overall they were more hurt than I was. But they enjoyed it more. When we were leaving, I was swearing never to come again where everyone else was planning returning the next weekend.
So, after these two back-to-back outdoor incidents, I’ve realized that letting yourself fall, if that’s the most probable result right at that moment, is not a bad idea. It has more benefits than trying to forcefully take yourself out of it. Because you will end up with nothing. Try to be a perfectionist but get there after perfecting your skills which you can only do by a systematic rinse-and-repeat procedure - let yourself fail, don’t feel embarrassed about the fail, fail fast, learn from the failure, make yourself better rectifying the mistake. Now rinse-and-repeat.

item.title: About LightPaper
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
About LightPaper

[This document is best viewed in Preview mode. Swipe from right to left to switch to Preview mode.]

★ New in Version 1.2

  • Sorting for file lists, by name, size or date, ascending or descending.
  • Settings Menu, which currently let's the user select the default sharing option, as well as the file lists sorting options.
  • Better syncing of the Preview view to the Editing view.
  • Better support for sharing documents to LightPaper from other apps.

★ New in Version 1.1

  • Search for documents.
  • More sharing options - plain text, HTML text, HTML file, and Markdown file.
  • Menu overflow button is now always visible for most devices.
  • Better external keyboard support with new shortcuts.

LightPaper is a simple, beautiful, text and Markdown editor for passionate writers. You can use LightPaper to write any kind of text documents - blogs, articles, notes, READMEs, TODOs, or the next chapter of your new novel. Its simple interface gets out of your way, allowing you to focus on writing. Your mobile editing experience will be enriched with the help of undo/redo, spell checking, and quick movement keys. To remove distractions, you can switch to Distraction Free Mode to completely immerse yourself in your current paragraph.

Dropbox Integration

The documents are saved locally by default, with the option to sync with and upload your documents to the cloud through Dropbox. To link to Dropbox, just select the Dropbox icon from Action Bar:

Markdown Support

LightPaper comes with built-in support for Markdown syntax. If you don't know Markdown and don't want to, it's okay - you can write everything in plain text. But we highly recommend you spare a few minutes to learn more about Markdown following this link: http://links.clockworkengine.com/mkdn.

From the author of Markdown:

Markdown is a text-to-HTML conversion tool for web writers. Markdown allows you to write using an easy-to-read, easy-to-write plain text format, then convert it to structurally valid XHTML (or HTML).

Previewing Markdown Document

If you have formatted your document using Markdown, previewing your document is just one swipe away - just swipe from right to left. To switch back to edit mode, swipe from left to right.

Editor Features

  • Markdown Shortcodes: Shortcodes are used to help speed up markdown editing. These Shortcodes come in two flavors, 'insert before', and 'surround'.

  • Distraction Free Mode: Use distraction free mode to highlight the paragraph being worked on. To leave Distraction Free Mode, click the distraction free icon.

  • Fast Text Navigation Keys: Use the fast text navigation keys to move forward and back in your text, either character by character, or word by word.

  • Sync With Dropbox: Use the Dropbox icon to connect to Dropbox and to automatically sync your files in the cloud. Files with conflicting names will be automatically renamed with an identifying digit.

Preview

The Preview View is used to preview the text or Markdown document currently being edited. To get to the Preview View, swipe from right to left on the Editor View.

File List

To get to the File List, either edge swipe the Editor or Preview pane left bezel, or click the upper left LightPaper icon. The sorting direction for the file list can be selected in the settings menu.

Folders

  • Documents: On by default, click the documents icon to see all files that are neither favorites nor trash. All new documents will begin life in the documents folder.
  • Favorites: Favorite documents are stored in the Favorite folder.
  • Trash: Files sent to the trash are stored here. From here, they may be removed from the trash, or deleted permanently.

Search

Click the search icon to perform a search across the file names.

Long press a file to get to file options

  • Favorite Icon: If the favorite button is empty, press the icon to send the document to the favorites folder. If the button is filled in, press the icon to remove the document from the favorites folder and send it back to the documents folder.
  • Share Icon: Press the share icon to share the document with another application.
  • Trash Icon: Press the trash icon to move the document to the trash folder.

  • Remove from Trash Icon: Press the 'remove from trash' icon to remove the document from trash, and send it back to the document folder.
  • Delete Icon: Press the delete icon to permanently remove the document from the trash folder.

Bluetooth Keyboard Support

Shortcuts:

  • new document: Ctrl N
  • save document: Ctrl S
  • undo: Ctrl Z
  • redo: Ctrl Y
  • redo: Ctrl Shift Z
  • move forward one word: Ctrl Right/Left Arrow
  • move to the beginning of the current line: Alt Left Arrow
  • move to the end of the current line: Alt Right Arrow

Sharing Options

Documents can be shared in four ways, 'Plain Text', 'HTML Text' (text after the markdown processor has rendered the text), 'HTML File', and Markdown File.

★ Settings

Settings are located in the Options menu, and can be used to choose the default Sharing Options, as well as the sorting options for files. Files may be sorted by name, size or date, ascending or descending.

Feedback and Comments

We'd love to hear from you. The best way to contact us is either by using our Google+ page, or by using Twitter. To get the latest updates on LightPaper you can like our Google+ page (http://links.clockworkengine.com/gpluslp) and follow us on Twitter @LightPaperApp. If you find LightPaper to be awesome, don't forget to 5 star us on the Google Play Store. We have made our best efforts to give Android users a simple, beautiful, and native looking editor and we promise to continuously improve it.

We hope you enjoy using it as much as we enjoyed writing it.

Team LightPaper http://getlightpaper.com

Clockwork Engine, LLC http://clockworkengine.com
